Letâ€™s just be perfectly clear. Thatâ€™s what happened,â€ Donalds explained. â€œThereâ€™s no reason why we couldnâ€™t do the money to get shots in arms, the money to actually help people who have lost their job through COVID-19, not just sending checks out to everybody, because the truth of the matter is, not everybody whoâ€™s going to get a check is on unemployment. That is not true. A lot of people are going to get checks who are working right now today. This is the way they do things. There was no way to get support for that monstrosity unless you were buying off members of Congress, and thatâ€™s why the thing is almost two trillion dollars.â€The House passed the massive spending bill last Saturday at around 2:00 a.m. almost entirely along party lines, 219â€“212, with zero Republicans and all but two Democrats voting in favor of it. The Senate, after a more than 24-hour long session debating various aspects of the package, passed the bill today, 50â€“49, again without a single Republican voting for it.Donalds said of House Republicansâ€™ sweeping opposition to the bill, â€œEvery time we see a piece of liberal policy, you oppose it, on grounds of principle and on grounds of fact. Thatâ€™s just what you saw out of the Republican side of the House of Representatives when it came to the COVID-19 wasteful spending stimulus bill.â€Later at the conference, Rep. Jim Jordan (R-OH) also ripped the bill as wasteful, telling Breitbart News, â€œI think weâ€™re at the point where Americans are now like, â€˜Look, itâ€™s time to get back to normal, not spend another two trillion dollars on a bunch of ridiculous things that arenâ€™t directly related to dealing with the virus itself.â€Following its passage in the Senate, many Senate Republicans released scathing statements about the partisan package, and theÂ National Republican Senatorial CommitteeÂ put outÂ a list of several of the irrelevant items included in the Democratsâ€™ â€œspending spree,â€ including items related to â€œenvironmental justice,â€ â€œracial justice,â€ and taxpayer-funded abortion.Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer on Saturday praised â€œthe American Rescue Planâ€ as â€œbig, bold, urgent COVID relief for people across this country.â€House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer (D-MD)Â saidÂ in a statement the House will vote on the Senate-version of the bill on Tuesday.Write to Ashley Oliver at aoliver@breitbart.com.HealthPoliticsByron Donaldscoronaviruscoronavirus reliefCPAC 2021On the Hill.Please let us know if you're having issues with commenting.Copyright Â© 2021 Breitbart

The Moderate Left vs. the Extreme Leftâ€œBig Labor May Save New York From AOCâ€™s Socialism:Â Even public-sector unions favor old-style incumbent Democrats to radical insurgents like her.â€ That was the headlineÂ atop an opinion piece in theÂ Wall Street JournalÂ onÂ February 19,Â referring, of course, to the extreme leftism of Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.Â In the piece, Steven Malanga argues that New York Cityâ€™s labor unions are opposing AOC because sheâ€™s too left-wing for them.Â  And this issue matters most immediately because the nationâ€™s largest and most influential city will elect a new mayor this year.Â  AOC herself is not a candidate, but she will seek to help elect a like-minded comrade.Â  Â In addition, New York state, dominated by the city, will hold gubernatorial and senatorial elections next year, and AOC is considered to be a potential primary challenger to Sen. Chuck Schumer. Â According to Malanga, the unions know that AOC is aligned with the Democratic Socialists of America (DSA), an outfit that routinely attacks unions for being insufficiently left-wing; Malanga quotes the DSAâ€™s declared strategy for â€œmilitant . . . classwide struggles.â€Â  However, most unionized workers are interested in bigger paychecks and greater benefits, not the revolutionary stuff of, say, Cuba or Venezuela. Â Indeed, unions blame AOC for blocking Amazonâ€™s expansion into New York City, which would have brought in 25,000 jobs, as well as billions in wages and revenues.Â As one construction union chief said of her influence, â€œPolitics and pandering have won out over a once-in-a-generation investment in New York Cityâ€™s economy.â€We might note that when Malanga talks about unions as a bulwark against socialism, heâ€™s not just talking about construction unions, which are traditionally somewhat conservative; heâ€™s also talking public employee unions, including the teachersâ€™ union.Â  Needless to say, nobody thinks of the teachersâ€™ unions as conservativeâ€”unless, of course, one is comparing them to AOC and the DSA. Â At the same time, nobody thinks of the Wall Street Journal as a pro-labor union publication.Â So when the Journal lauds unions as a bulwark against hard-leftism, the relationship is entirely tactical: If and when the threat from AOC goes away, the Journalâ€™s affection for unions will also go away.Â Yet almost certainly, AOC is not going away.Â Indeed, at age 31, she rates now as one of the brightest stars in the Democratic Party, and she could continue to shine for decades to come. Â So AOCâ€™s likely long-term presenceâ€”and threatâ€”might cause Republicans to think about their traditional, mostly hostile stance toward labor unions. The GOP might need the unions, just as Malanga says, as an additional bulwark against socialism. Â Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-NY) leaves the U.S. Capitol after passage of the stimulus bill on March 27, 2020 in Washington, DC. (Win McNamee/Getty Images)So that raises a tantalizing possibility: Perhaps the Republican Party will wish to actively court the labor vote.Â The Democrats have a firm grip on the urban left, and they also have been doing well in affluent suburbs.Â Today, virtually all the suburban House seats around big cities such as New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, and Philadelphia are represented by Democrats, and the Dems have even gained seats in suburban Atlanta, Houston, and Dallas.Â In fact, Democrats hold the seats representing the ten wealthiest Congressional districts in America, as well as 41 of the top 50.Â Yes, of course, Republicans should look to win back as many of those seats as possible, and yet at the same time, we should realize that the two parties are in the midst of an historic realignmentâ€”as Democrats become the party of the rich (and the poor), while Republicans become the party of the middle.Â  Â As it happens, just last year, this author wrote a piece for Breitbart News headlined, â€œâ€˜Essential Workersâ€™ Point the Way to a Republican Workers Party,â€ and then a few weeks later followed it up with a similarly themed piece, â€œThe Republican Party of Cops, Nurses, and Other Workersâ€”All Together.â€Since then, leading Republican figures such as House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy, Sen. Josh Hawley, Sen. Marco Rubio, andÂ Sen. Rick ScottÂ have declared that the GOP is now the â€œworkers party.â€Â Moreover, a new NBC News poll bears McCarthy out: Support for Republicans is rising among the White working class, as well as among the Hispanic and Black working class.Â  Â To be sure, the Democrats wonâ€™t easily give up their claim to the working class. President Joe Biden has a decades-long connection to labor leadership, and just last week he brought labor chieftains to the White House, declaring, â€œI want to make it clear Iâ€™m a labor guy.â€ Â Yet on the other hand, Biden supported the free-trade deals that are anathema to unions, including the North American Free Trade Agreement, Permanent Normal Trade Relations with China, and the Trans-Pacific Partnership.Â People hold placards during a protest in support of Amazon workers in Union Square, New York, on February 20, 2021. (KENA BETANCUR/AFP via Getty Images)MoreÂ recently, the Biden administration had been curiously quiet about the attempt of Amazon workers in Bessemer, Alabama, to unionize;Â that unionization vote, of course, pits workersÂ against the mighty Jeff Bezos, CEO of Amazon and owner of theÂ Washington Post. Finally, on February 28, just as the votingÂ was starting, Biden released a videoÂ urging the workers to vote but conspicuously notÂ telling them which way to vote, yea or nay on the union. So we can see: Biden seems to need the good will of Bezos andÂ the Post just as much asÂ he needs the workers. Â In other words, â€œMiddle Class Joe,â€ the fella born in blue-collar Scranton, PA, must contend with â€œGlobalist Joe,â€ who takes his cues from Wall Street, Hollywood, and Big Tech.Â These neoliberal nodes support not only free trade, but also a slew of social and cultural issues that fall into the category of â€œwoke.â€ Â Yet perhaps the greatest flashpoint is another cause connected to wokeism, namely,Â environmentalism.Â The Greens Defeat the Blue CollarsFor a half-century or more, one piercing critique of the green movement is that it has pursued exotic environmental goals at the expense of jobs and economic growth.Â  That is, the mostly affluent greens have been besting the non-affluent blues (blue collars).Indeed, one can look at the brief track record of the new Biden administration and see already that the greens are winningâ€”perhaps because the 46th president owes more to green donors than to ordinary voters.Â Thus Biden hired John Kerry, the ultimate environmental elitist, to be his â€œclimate czar,â€ and on his first day in the Oval Office, he killed the Keystone Pipeline, taking away thousands of blue-collar jobs. Â Yet of course, greens want still more, and they even want it to be Greta Thunberg-friendly.Â As the trendy-left New Republic magazine argued, â€œCanceling the Keystone XL pipeline was a solid start.Â But the Biden administration needs to do more than reward the youth climate movement with opening-month executive orders.â€ [emphasis added]Â Yes, thatâ€™s what avant-garde greens want now: a specific Biden pander to the â€œyouth climate movement,â€ which consists, of course, mostly of the children of rich green liberals; the magazine suggested â€œestablishing a youth council to advise the Biden administration on climate and other policy matters.â€Â Ah yes, just what the nation needs: a White House office to host trust-fund kids. Â In the meantime, the young adults of blue-collar Middle America are more likely to be looking for jobs or perhaps attending a state college. Â Out of this obvious class cleavage, green vs. blue, we can see political peril for Democratsâ€”and opportunity for Republicans. Â A February 21 headline in Politico spelled it out: â€œBiden squeezed between promises to go green and bolster unions.â€Â  As the article detailed, Biden will have to decide whether to import solar panels from China, so as to reach his carbon targets sooner and cheaper, or else to insist that the solar panels be made in the USA. Â In the meantime, blue-collar labor chieftains are noticing that their people are getting the short end of the stick. As Terry Oâ€™Sullivan, general president of the Laborersâ€™ International Union of North America, told Politico:Itâ€™s pie-in-the-sky bull[bleep] about these green jobs being good middle-class jobs, because theyâ€™re not.Â  Iâ€™m concerned about union members and union families being left behind . . .Â  and I think theyâ€™ve already been left behind.So now we can see the Republican opportunity: to swoop in and come down, hard, on the side of the workers.Â That is, not just to champion the Keystone Pipeline, but also to demand that the Green New Deal, if there must be one, be Made in USA.Â (As this author has argued, and as Rep. Matt Gaetz has also argued, a carbon-reduction plan that included rural carbon capture could actually be a boon to the boonies.)Â In this photo from February 27, 2012, workers assemble solar panels by hand on the factory floor of the Chinese company Suntech in the eastern Chinese city of Wuxi. The success of Chinese companies like Suntech, the worldâ€™s biggest producer of solar panels, became a trade issue as American companies have accused them of dumping in the U.S. market and receiving unfair subsidies from Beijing. (PETER PARKS/AFP via Getty Images)Solidarity Is Not WokeWorking people are not woke.Â Yes, they want clean air and clean water, but the avant-garde preoccupations of Manhattan and Beverly Hills are not their preoccupations.Â Regular folks are focused on paying the rent or the mortgage, not on alleviating their guilt. Â If Republicans want the votes of blue collarsâ€”including Hispanic blue collarsâ€”a decent respect should be paid to their opinions; yes, workers tend to be against abortion, against gun control, and against wokery, and yet they are in favor of things too, including higher wages, a dignified workplace in which they have an organized voice, and guaranteed health care.In other words, the working class is less libertarian and more communitarianâ€”the Bible is a lot more popular than Atlas Shrugged.Â Moreover, if workers get their fair share, they will also be against The Communist ManifestoÂ or whatever watered-down version of that sinister document AOC and the DSA might be trying to peddle.Â Why?Â Because if working people have a piece of the pie, they will want to protect it.Â And so they will be, yes, a bulwark against socialism. Â For the non-rich, non-poorâ€”the folks in the middleâ€”a key ideal is solidarity: all for one and one for all.Â  Â Itâ€™s that spirit of solidarity that smart politicians have always been able to to tap into.Â For instance, hereâ€™sÂ Franklin D. Roosevelt, speaking to a blue-collar audience in Boston in 1944, when World War Two was summoning up the best in all Americans regardless of ethnicity or class:Â Today, in this war, our fine boys are fighting magnificently all over the world and among those boys are the Murphys and the Kellys, the Smiths and the Joneses, the Cohens, the Carusos, the Kowalskis, the Schultzes, the Olsens, the Swobodas, andâ€”right in with all the rest of themâ€”the Cabots and the Lowells. Â  All of these people, and others like them, are the life-blood of America.We can observe that this is the way the vast majority of Americans wish to think of themselves: as patriots in the melting pot of Team America, ready to do their fair shareâ€”perhaps even, if need be, making the ultimate sacrificeâ€”as long as everyone is expected to be a part of the overall effort.Â Itâ€™s that non-shirking spirit that wins wars and makes a nation great.Â Today, moreover, we could update FDRâ€™s speech and include in the melting pot â€œthe Garcias,â€ â€œthe Khans,â€ â€œthe Patels,â€ and â€œthe Yangs.â€Â Applied to the homefront, this all-together spirit means solidarity in the workplace.Â As Breitbart Newsâ€™ Rebecca Mansour observed, â€œThereâ€™s something universal about workers and power structures and the politics of left/right.Â The working class is not prone to socialism.Â Theyâ€™re prone to unionism.â€Â And so, she added, echoing the Journalâ€™s Steven Malanga, â€œUnions have beenâ€”and should beâ€”the bulwark against socialism and communism.â€A Case Study in Winning SolidarityÂ Dwight Eisenhower, West Point class of 1915, was a careerist in that most solidaristic of institutions: the U.S. military.Â Having led millions of men and women to victory in the European Theater of World War Two, he could easily see the value of solidarity on the homefront. Â As Ike said in a presidential campaign speech to the American Federation of Labor in New York City on September 17, 1952:Today in America unions have a secure place in our industrial life. Only a handful of unreconstructed reactionaries harbor the ugly thought of breaking unions.Â Only a fool would try to deprive working men and women of the right to join the union of their choice.That November, Ike was indeed well-liked: He won more than 55 percent of the national popular vote, carrying 39 of 48 statesâ€”including New York State.Â  Â And once in office, the 34th president, a Republican, was careful to balance capital and labor; he was pro-business, and yet he was also pro-labor.Â That was attested by a 1956 re-election campaign handbill, published by the Young Republican Labor Committee; the sheet features a cartoon of a happy worker-elephant carrying a proletarian lunchbox and touting such bullet points as, â€œINCREASED UNION MEMBERSHIP.â€Â One hardly need mention that Eisenhower was victorious in that campaign as well, winning a second and even largerÂ landslide.Â Okay, so now we can fast-forward to the 1980s, when Ronald Reaganâ€”the only president ever to possess a working union cardâ€”declared, â€œOne of the most elemental human rights [is] the right to belong to a free trade union.â€Â At that time in 1982, Reagan was referring to the dissident shipyard workers of Gdansk, Poland, led by a fiercely anti-communistÂ activist Lech Walesa, who started a wildcat union, Solidarnosc (Solidarity). And ofÂ course, within lessÂ than a decade, Walesa and hisÂ fellow workers,Â joined by otherÂ patriotic Poles, hadÂ overthrown the communist government in Warsaw. Now thatâ€™s theÂ sort of union activism that the AOC types fear. Â Friends and relatives of striking workers listen to the news given by Lech Walesa (C) outside the gates of the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk, Poland, on August 25, 1980. The strike in the Gdansk shipyard lasted from August 13 to 31, along with other strikes which paralyzed the whole country. It finished by an agreement between the Polish government and the strikersâ€™ joint committee, which sanctioned free and independent unions with the right to strike and greater freedom of religious and political expression. The newly-born trade union â€œSolidarnoscâ€ (Solidarity) was an unprecedented working-class revolution directed against the communist government, and it quickly developed into a 10-million-strong independent organization. (JORMA PUUSA/AFP via Getty Images)Oh, and did we mention that Reagan won two monster presidential landslides in 1980 and 1984?Â And yes, both times, he carried New York state, unions and all.Â  For the most part, that was the way Republicans were back then; they saw themselves as governmental stewards, not ideological warriors.Â It was their job to steer the ship of state on a prudent courseâ€“including, as needed, sharp turns to the rightâ€“and the blue collars and Northerners in general were on board with that stewardship.Â Then, in the 1990s, the GOP began to change. The tilt in the party, toward the South, became unmistakable, and so Yankees no longer felt at home.Â Some in Dixie no doubt said, â€œGood riddance,â€ and yet if people leave a party, they take their votes with them.Â For proof, letâ€™s look at the data: From 1952 to 1988, the GOP won seven of ten presidential elections, averaging 51.6 percent of the national vote.Â By contrast, in the last eight presidential elections, 1992 to 2020, the GOP has lost five, averaging a mere 45.3 percent of the vote. Â So now that Republicans are out of power in the White House, as well as out of power in both chambers of Congress, maybe itâ€™s time to start thinking about where the GOP might find more votes.Republican presidential candidate Ronald Reagan promised to rebuild Americaâ€™s merchant marine fleet during a speech before the National Maritime Union in St. Louis, Missouri, on Oct. 9, 1980. After his speech, the Republican nominee won a standing ovation and the endorsement of the 35,000-member union. (AP Photo/Charles W. Harrity)The Future Victory CoalitionLast October, the data firm Echelon Insights studied the American electorate, dividing it into five broad blocs.Â One of these is the Trump MAGA/America First grouping, which accounts for just 16 percent of the electorate.So thatâ€™s a sobering realization right there: The overtly Trumpy vote is less a sixth of the total.Â That percentage might be enough to win Republican primaries, but itâ€™s definitely not enough to win many statewide contests, to stay nothing of a national election.Thus we can see: The MAGA group needs allies.Poster created by the Young Republicans Labor Committee for Labor Day 1956. (Susan H. Douglas Political Americana Collection, Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library)According to Echelon, the other blocs are as follows: Ronald Reagan-ish conservatives account for 25 percent; Mike Bloomberg-type urbanites and suburbanites total 11 percent; Joe Bidenite labor liberals amount to 26 percent; and AOC-type leftists are 11 percent. Â We can quickly gather that the best fit for the MAGA 16 percent is the Reaganite 25 percent, although to make that a firm alliance, there will have to be some compromising and kumbaya-ing.Â Just like marriages, thatâ€™s the way coalitions have to workâ€”or else they donâ€™t work. Â Yet still, that 16 and 25 adds up only to 41, and we need to get to 50+1.Â So where could the rest of the votes come from?Â  From what other bloc?Â Many analysts suggest that the new Republican votes will come from the ranks of Biden labor liberals and even, yes, from Bernie Sanders types further to the leftâ€”but thatâ€™s the union-minded populist left, not the woke-minded progressive left.Â  Â The populists, of course, are the folks who were solidly with the Democrats when they were the party of FDR, and yet not so much when they became the party of wokesters.Â Indeed, one suspects that Biden himself feels more comfortable with the Old Democrats, as opposed to the Woke Democrats.Â Yes, that might be the case for Olâ€™ Joeâ€”but now, having made the bargain to be president, heâ€™ll never tell.Â Unless, of course, he blurts it all out.Â And if he were to do so, wouldnâ€™t that be something, as he exploded the Democratic coalition?Most likely, though, Republicans wonâ€™t get that lucky.Â Instead, we ourselves will have to do the hard work of coalition-building, assembling blocs of blue collars, thereby building a majority rainbow coalition of those willing to work, those reverent for tradition, and those respectful of law and order. As Eisenhower and Reagan proved, thereâ€™s a majority there. Â  Interestingly, just on March 2, the Republican-dominated Montana state legislature voted down right-to-work legislation, with nearly half theÂ RepublicansÂ joining with the minority Democrats to support the continuation of Montanaâ€™s union-friendly environment. Right-to-work is an intensely controversialÂ issue with plenty ofÂ Republicans on the anti-union side, and yet at a time when Americaâ€™s biggest and richest companies have lined up with the Democratsâ€“and anti-labor operatives are moving into theÂ Biden administrationâ€“it only makes sense thatÂ Republicans will continue to move toward more pro-worker positions. BERLIN (AP) â€“ Companies that sell refrigerators, washers, hairdryers or TVs in the European Union will need to ensure those appliances can be repaired for up to 10 years, to help reduce the vast mountain of electrical waste that piles up each year on the continent.The â€œright to repair,â€ as it is sometimes called, comes into force across the 27-nation bloc Monday. It is part of a broader effort to cut the environmental footprint of manufactured goods by making them more durable and energy efficient.â€œThis is a really big step in the right directionâ€ said Daniel Affelt of the environmental group BUND-Berlin, which runs several â€œrepair cafesâ€ where people can bring in their broken appliances and get help fixing them up again.Modern appliances are often glued or riveted together, he said. â€œIf you need specialist tools or have to break open the device, then you canÂ´t repair it.â€Lack of spare parts is another problem, campaigners say. Sometimes a single broken tooth on a tiny plastic sprocket can throw a proverbial wrench in the works.â€œPeople want to repair their appliances,â€ Affelt said. â€œWhen you tell them that there are no spare parts for a device thatÂ´s only a couple of years old then they are obviously really frustrated by that.â€Under the new EU rules, manufacturers will have to ensure parts are available for up to a decade, though some will only be provided to professional repair companies to ensure they are installed correctly.New devices will also have to come with repair manuals and be made in such a way that they can be dismantled using conventional tools when they really canâ€™t be fixed anymore, to improve recycling.Each year, Europeans produce more than 16 kilograms (35 pounds) of electrical waste per person. About half of that junk is due to broken household appliances, and the EU recycles only about 40% of it, leaving behind huge amounts of potentially hazardous material.German Environment Minister Svenja Schulze said that in a next step, manufacturers should have to state how long a product is expected to work for and repair it if it breaks down earlier. This would encourage companies to build more durable products, she said.â€œIn the repair cafes we see a lot of devices that broke shortly after the warranty expired,â€ said Affelt â€“ a phenomenon that has prompted some environmentalists to accuse manufacturers of designing their devices with planned obsolescence.Knowing an appliance will really last for a decade might prompt consumers to choose products that are more durable or can be easily fixed, he said.â€œFor the vast majority of devices, repair is the right choice,â€ said Affelt, adding that the exception might be old, inefficient refrigerators that can contain powerful greenhouse gases which fuel climate change.In a next step, environmentalists and consumer rights groups want the â€œright to repairâ€ expanded to include smartphones, laptops and other small electrical devices.Responding to growing demand, Apple last year announced it would start providing training and spare parts to certified independent repair stores fixing Mac computers, not just iPhones.Right to repair bills have been introduced in several U.S. state legislatures, attracting bipartisan support, though as yet there is no nationwide measure in force.Sweden has gone further than most of the EU, making repairs and spare parts subject to lower value-added tax.The blocâ€™s ecological design directive â€“ of which the right to repair requirement is a part â€“ will also revise existing energy labels that describe how much electricity washers and other household devices consume.
